hedline.hl1: Boeing 757 Nearly Lands on Closed Runway at Newark, but Air Traffic Controller Intercedes

abstract.p: Continental Airlines plane nearly lands on a closed runway at Newark Airport, but an air traffic controller notices the impending mistake and orders the plane up before it can land (M)

block.p: A Continental Airlines plane nearly landed on a closed runway at Newark Airport before dawn yesterday, but an air traffic controller noticed the impending mistake and ordered the plane up before it could land.

The plane, on a red-eye flight from San Francisco, was cleared to land on one of two parallel runways at 6:15 a.m., a slow time for the normally busy airport, said James Peters, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration. But the pilot aligned the jet, a Boeing 757, with the left-hand runway instead of the right-hand one.

A Continental Airlines plane nearly landed on a closed runway at Newark Airport before dawn yesterday, but an air traffic controller noticed the impending mistake and ordered the plane up before it could land.

The plane, on a red-eye flight from San Francisco, was cleared to land on one of two parallel runways at 6:15 a.m., a slow time for the normally busy airport, said James Peters, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration. But the pilot aligned the jet, a Boeing 757, with the left-hand runway instead of the right-hand one.
Just as the plane reached the runway's threshold, the air traffic controller handling the flight noticed, Mr. Peters said, and ordered the pilot to ''go around.''
The pilot ''powered up, circled the field, came back and landed on the first runway,'' Mr. Peters said.

He said that such ''go-arounds'' or ''missed approaches'' -- when a pilot cannot execute a planned landing -- happened several times a day at busy airports like Newark. Sometimes they are requested by pilots, other times by controllers, but they rarely occur because a plane is heading for the wrong runway, he said.
Both the controller and the pilot followed go-around procedures correctly, said Mr. Peters, adding that no one was hurt and that the flight was not delayed.
Mr. Peters said the flight standards district office at Teterboro Airport would investigate the incident by obtaining tapes of ground-to-air communications and radar data showing the flight's path.
The incident occurred as an airport duty manager, Dan Harvey, was inspecting the runway, which had been closed for routine electrical maintenance, officials said.
Mr. Harvey was monitoring air traffic on his car radio and heard the controller's instructions, then saw the plane emerge from the morning fog, said Steve Coleman, an airport duty manager.
Mr. Peters, the Federal Aviation spokesman, said it was too early to speculate on what caused the mistake. An automated information service for pilots was announcing that 22-Left was closed, he said.

A union official defended the air traffic controller, a 13-year veteran. Daniel D'Agostino, president of the Newark division of the National Air Traffic Controllers Association, told The Associated Press that tapes of air-to-ground communication showed that the pilot had misunderstood the controller's instructions.
Catherine Stengel, a spokeswoman for Continental Airlines, said the company did not know what instructions the pilot had received nor how quickly he had responded to the go-around order.
